case_vignette:
A 32-year-old Caucasian man presents to the physician because of the swelling and discomfort of the right testis for 3 weeks. There is no history of trauma, fever, or night sweats. He had surgery for an undescended right testis when he was 6 months old. There is no history of liver disease or hypogonadism. He has fathered 2 children. He takes no medications and denies any illicit drug use. The vital signs are within normal limits. Palpation of the scrotum reveals a firm nontender mass that cannot be separated from the right testis. Examination of the left testis shows no abnormalities. There is no supraclavicular or inguinal lymphadenopathy. Gynecomastia is present. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Ultrasound shows an enlarged right testicle with a hypoechoic mass replacing a large portion of the normal architecture. The left testis is normal. The laboratory test results are as follows:
HCG Elevated
AFP Elevated
LDH Normal
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having swelling and discomfort in my right testicle for the past 3 weeks.
Could you tell me if you have had any recent trauma or injury to the area?
No, I haven't had any recent trauma or injury to the area.
Do you have any history of urinary tract infections or sexually transmitted infections?
It's not mentioned in my history.
Do you have a fever or chills?
No, I don't have a fever or chills.
Do you have any history of testicular cancer in your family?
No, there's no history of testicular cancer in my family.

Based on your symptoms and history, I suspect you may be suffering from epididymitis, which is an inflammation of the coiled tube (epididymis) at the back of the testicle that stores and carries sperm. It is often caused by a bacterial infection. I recommend you see a healthcare professional for a thorough evaluation and appropriate management.

**Final Diagnosis:** Epididymitis
